content: Going to publish my first package / crate soon..I think I'm preferring snake_case just for consistency, but can anyone give me a counterargument as to why I shouldnt use snake_case for my package name? I am also considering naming it "rust_my_name" to differentiate from my other projects in other languages in my github too.
Plz let me know if this type of Q is best asked in the discord, I realize it isn't a Rust internals Q.

If you mean snake_case vs. kebab-case, both are quite popular. I think the latter looks nicer, but can lead to some ambiguities that are generally handled well. Adding rust_ or rust- or -rs, it's generally frowned upon because it's already clear you're in Rust and typing meta_vars_rs::foo() gets old pretty quickly.

Got it, thanks! I'll drop the rust_ prefix. As for snake_case vs kebab-case... I can't get over the fact that _semantically_ it just feels like an outer module or namespace so outer_name::inner_thing_name::innerest_thing_name just feels consistent. idk.
caffeinateoften has marked this topic as resolved.
I see it like "crate name is meta-vars, but the Rust syntax requires you to type it as meta_vars"

The package name is meta-vars, but the crate name is meta_vars. The crate name doesn't even have to be similar to the package name. Note that crate is a rustc concept meaning a single compilation unit, while package is a cargo concept meaning a collection of crates where at most one is a library, with any number of binaries, examples and tests.

caffeinateoften said:

I am also considering naming it "rust_my_name" to differentiate from my other projects in other languages in my github too.

You could consider naming the github repo rust-cool-widget even if the crate is cool-widget. That can definitely be handy when cloning a bunch of things to the same folder locally.
